section.title: Patient Safety Overview
section.para: Integrated Knowledge Exchange (IKE) is a set of principles, tools and methods that are designed to make doing the right thing easier. One of those “right things” is patient safety. First and foremost, our health information must do no harm to the patient. IKE enables more accurate, complete, precise, and higher-quality health data that is safer to use for clinical decision-making. Low quality health data management practices can lead to under treatment, over treatment, or delayed treatment resulting in preventable patient harm. [16]

section.title: Patient Safety – Then and Now
section.para: Patient safety has been defined as the “prevention of harm to patients.” [17] To achieve patient safety, the whole system of healthcare must prevent errors, learn from the errors that occur, and develop a culture of safety similar to other high-risk industries such as aviation.

Patient safety efforts have mostly focused on investigation of adverse events after they have occurred. This is reactive safety and while important for learning from errors, it is insufficient in reducing common adverse events such as medication errors, surgical complications, or diagnostic errors. [18]

Proactive safety attempts to design or redesign systems, processes, and methods based on leading indicators of increased risk, poor quality, or identified flaws before an adverse event occurs. Examples of proactive safety practices include hazard analysis, safety reporting, audits, tracers, training, testing, and surveys to measure the culture of safety.

Developing a culture of safety includes establishing a non-punitive response to error which is also known as a just culture. Just culture is a balance between learning from error and accountability. [19] Absent a just culture, it is unlikely practitioners will self-report errors due to fear of retribution, loss of employment, or legal action. Blaming an individual or team for system errors prevents learning from errors, impedes continuous improvement, and reinforces silence when system vulnerabilities are discovered.

Since the 1999 report, To Err is Human, was published by the Institute of Medicine, patient safety has received more attention across the healthcare ecosystem due to the prevalence of preventable patient harm. A short review of these important patient safety publications documents key milestones for system improvement opportunities and required changes to reduce preventable patient harm.

listitem.para: To Err is Human (1999) – described the breadth and depth of preventable harm and the challenge of improving patient safety. It was estimated that nearly 100,000 Americans died as a result of preventable patient harm. [20] In 2016, a study from Johns Hopkins researchers estimated annual patient deaths at more than 250,000 Americans making preventable patient harm the 3 rd leading cause of death in the USA behind cardiac disease and cancer. [21]

Crossing the Quality Chasm (2001) – described the quality gaps in healthcare, how current practices degrade quality, and how to take systems approaches to improve quality. Aims for quality improvement included safety as system property, effectiveness, patient-centeredness, timeliness, efficiency, and equity regardless of gender, ethnicity, geographic location, or socio-economic status. The report furthered the need for digitized health information systems. [22]

Health IT and Patient Safety (2012) – described both the promise of health IT and the potential patient safety risks of poorly designed, improperly configured, and mismanaged electronic patient data and health IT systems. The report further highlighted the importance of the human-machine (including software) interface to prevent diagnostic errors and improve clinical decision making. Health IT vendors, regulators, and health systems were encouraged to find ways to mitigate identified health IT risks and the unintended consequences of the Meaningful Use criteria as part of the Health Information Technology for Economic and Clinical Health (HITECH) Act of 2009. [23]

Improving Diagnosis in Health Care (2015) – described the importance of reducing the prevalence of diagnostic errors across the healthcare system including missed diagnosis, delayed diagnosis, and incorrect diagnosis resulting in undertreatment, overtreatment, suboptimal standard of care, and preventable patient harm. It is estimated that every American will experience at least one diagnostic error during the lifetime. High quality health information is critical for improving diagnostic decision making. Clinicians and patients must be able to trust the underlying health data and health IT systems being used for diagnostic decision making. [24]

section.para: High reliability organization (HRO) principles from other safety critical industries such as commercial aviation and nuclear power began to be adopted as a patient safety framework in some healthcare settings (See Table 1). [25] The principles originated from social science as behaviors present in organizations which operated in extremely complex, high-risk environments with high levels of system reliability believed to produce safer outcomes. Reliability is the probability that a component or system will perform as designed under certain conditions over time (e.g., checklists). Leaders and managers can foster a culture supported by HRO principles that focuses on reducing errors at a single component level, also known as component failures (human or machine). [26] Limitations of this approach can seduce leaders into believing that worse case scenarios (losses, adverse events, accidents) have linear causality with the human as a possible weak link in the system. HRO methods rely on decomposition (breaking complex systems down into single components to analyze) rather than using systems theory to address highly complex, highly coupled systems such as healthcare data information systems. [27]

row.entry: Use informatics experts in health IT

section.para: Traditional safety approaches have become inadequate to address the increasing complexity of healthcare due to rapidly emerging technology, big data, and the advent of artificial intelligence (AI) across a dynamic health information ecosystem. To address the increasing complexity, healthcare institutions are beginning to leverage systems theory, systems thinking, and a systems approach to safety.

System Safety is rooted in systems theory where the whole, the designed system, is more than the sum of the parts. System Safety addresses the whole using a combination of systems and safety engineering approaches. Traditional safety methodologies such as root cause analysis (RCA) and Failure Modes and Effects Analysis (FMEA) focus on failures at a component level or as over-simplified human error. RCA and FMEA were developed before work systems incorporated software, computers, and other sophisticated technology such as AI. System Safety views patient safety as a control problem.

Engineering models can be developed and analyzed for safety and quality purposes throughout the system’s lifecycle from design through adoption. These system models are not schematics or flow charts; instead, they serve as abstract representations of highly complex sociotechnical relationships between a controller and the process being controlled. These relationships are known as control loops (Figure 1). [28]

Control loops are hierarchical with the Provider as a controller above the Patient, the controlled process in this example. The downward arrows represent the control actions that the controller uses to control the patient care process including assessments, exams, tests, imaging, treatments, and therapies. The upward arrows are feedback mechanisms the provider receives from the patient such as their medical history, symptoms, and health trends.

Without adequate feedback, the provider would not be able to make safe, high quality clinical decisions that meet the standard of care. The Provider controller develops a process model or belief system about each individual patient before making treatment decisions. Other information may be accessible through the patient’s EHR, a family member, or another patient advocate. Modelling the patient care system of interest builds on this control loop to include other essential control loops forming what’s known as a control structure. [29]

Once the control structure is fully modelled, either in the design or redesign phases of the system lifecycle, teams can conduct proactive and retrospective safety analyses to identify new requirements, system hazards, unsafe control actions, and missing feedback loops. The System Theoretic Process Analysis (STPA) method is most effective when used early in the design or redesign phase as a prospective safety analysis while the Causal Analysis based on Systems Theory (CAST) is used retrospectively to determine causal factors of adverse events such as preventable patient harm. [30]

Safety Management Systems (SMS) are used by high-risk industries such as aviation, military commands, health care, and nuclear power to reduce or eliminate hazards for safer outcomes. SMS is a formalized approach to safety decision-making, proactive safety management, safety culture promotion, and quality assurance. An effective SMS relies on a comprehensive safety information system that has leading indicators of safe performance, feedback from voluntary reporting, and passive data collection using software applications that monitor system control actions.

Safety data trends are reported to responsible parties including operators, supervisors, management, regulators, and other industry stakeholders. An SMS is an enabler for learning including knowledge sharing, policy effectiveness, and innovation. Key processes of an SMS include safety risk management and safety assurance. [31] SMS design is enhanced when system control structures are modelled, monitored, and audited using system safety engineering principles such as STPA.

Safety in a health data context includes clinical decision support, safe data exchange, and safe use of health data for regulatory oversight, research, and population health decision-making. Furthermore, poor data quality degrades patient safety especially among disparate health populations when using low quality data to train AI models for patient care. [32]

para.emphasis: Spotlight Case Study #1: STPA of the U.S. Diagnostic Laboratory Data Ecosystem

section.para: The STPA of the U.S. Diagnostic Laboratory Data Ecosystem, was a proactive analysis that sought to detail the operations of the complex, interdependent system both as a whole and of its respective components within and identify where – or where not – diagnostic laboratory data was fulfilling its goals of higher quality care.

Using STPA with interviews from 50 stakeholders, the research team developed a model of the ecosystem (control structure) and analyzed it to identify the causal factors in common types of adverse events related to diagnostic laboratory data and provided recommendations for improvement and system redesign. This analysis identified over 200 unsafe control actions (UCAs) and six main causal factors that contribute to two main recurring hazards: (1) patients receiving less than adequate care and (2) diminishing trust and/or reputation within the laboratory data ecosystem.
These six causal factors with their associated recommendation were:

listitem.para: Decentralized and missing oversight
Recommendation 1: Assign responsibility for addressing gaps in the regulatory oversight of laboratory data exchanges between system components that are regulated by different agencies.
Recommendation 2: Identify the data and standards needs of regulatory agencies and ensure they have the ability to use them appropriately.
Recommendation 3: Encourage the identification of regulatory gaps in other areas of the laboratory ecosystem through additional systems-theory-based analyses.
Inadequacies and gaps in laboratory data standards, including standards that are loosely constrained, ambiguous, and outdated

Recommendation 4: Reference libraries must develop a knowledge base that establishes a ground truth for naming, coding, and mapping of reference terminologies to particular laboratory tests, and stakeholders must be incentivized to use it.

Recommendation 5: Appropriate groups must be assigned responsibility for identifying gaps and weaknesses in laboratory data standards and for establishing a reporting channel for problems related to them.

Recommendation 6: Standards Development Organizations (LOINC®, SNOMED CT®, RxNorm, etc.) must continuously support users by identifying and eliminating ambiguities in implementation guides for HIT standards.
Inaccurate perceptions of risks with respect to both laboratory data and the use of HIT
Recommendation 7: Proactively and retroactively investigate systemic sources of diagnostic error.

Recommendation 8: Create a consolidated national database for HIT safety reporting that can be used to identify trends and opportunities for improving patient safety outcomes. It should include information about HIT not behaving as users intended and allow understanding how features of HIT design may have contributed to “user errors.”
Lack of a systems view by participants in the system
Recommendation 9: Educate the healthcare community on systems engineering and systemic approaches for solving problems, including tools to accomplish this goal.
Recommendation 10: Establish appropriate control loops for updates to standards and HIT.
Inadequate regulatory emphasis on the safety involved in health system information technology

Recommendation 11: Assign regulatory oversight of HIT safety to ONC or another appropriate group. Include the explicit directive to develop and include safety-related certification criteria for HIT and the ability to limit the inclusion of “hold harmless” clauses in HIT contracts.
Recommendation 12: Establish incentives for using certified HIT throughout the entire healthcare ecosystem.
Flawed communication and coordination

Recommendation 13: Develop formal processes for inclusion of laboratorians in the multidisciplinary teams responsible for decisions about laboratory data needs, representations, and interfaces at care facilities.

para.emphasis: UCA Scenario – Defining the Need for IKE

section.para: This following UCA identified during the STPA in Spotlight Case Study #1 where IKE solutioning would strengthen knowledge representation, improve data quality, and reduce patient risk.

UCA scenario: A medical practitioner may provide treatment that does not match the patient’s condition. One contributing factor may be that the practitioner does not have the diagnostic information to inform their mental model of the patient’s condition. The diagnostic information may not be observed by the medical practitioner because they may be accustomed to using their routine process to access results in the EHR, which only displays laboratory data that has been previously mapped to the care facility’s EHR system (e.g., mapped to a LOINC® code or local code representation). In some cases, additional unmapped test results are shared by the laboratory as a PDF and the physician may not notice due to its lack of salience in the EHR process flow. Physicians who are not expecting or looking for the test results may not be prompted to look for additional, unmapped information in a patient profile, particularly if the unmapped results were ordered by another physician or a long time ago. The results may have been shared as a PDF because they pertained to a new or uncommon test whose format could not be represented in the messaging standard available to that laboratory-care facility pair. Standards for new and complex tests (e.g., genomics) are not yet tightly constrained and can be shared as PDFs because Clinical Laboratory Improvement Amendments (CLIA) only requires that the data sent gets received and does not specify the method of transmission nor impose any requirement or confirmation that the information is observed by the medical practitioner. CLIA was drafted and approved in 1988, before EHRs were widely adopted and modifications to CLIA require Congressional approval. section.title: The Promise of Digital Health Information and Patient Safety
section.para: In the U.S., moving from paper charts to EHR systems is mostly complete (96%) with only 22% of office-based physician practices remaining paper-based. [33] Incentive programs such as Meaningful Use (MU) provided government funding through CMS for health systems and provider organizations to digitize their health information systems. From 2010-2020, MU program goals included digital data collection, data sharing, advanced clinical processes, and improved outcomes. Studies have shown that HIT has improved patient safety by reducing medication errors, avoiding adverse drug reactions, and increasing adherence to evidence-based medicine protocols. [34] While HIT has improved some clinical outcomes, the adoption, configuration, implementation, and maintenance of HIT has increased patient risk in other parts of the health delivery system due to unintended consequences of poorly managed HIT. [35]

First-generation HIT configurations have mostly been managed by HIT vendors who mainly focused on billing data and other administrative and operational data management functions (e.g., reimbursement, mandatory reporting, etc.). HIT adoption radically changed historic clinical workflows in an effort to standardize data inputs and system outputs. This “one size fits all” approach was resisted by clinicians creating configuration trade-offs, workarounds, and increased system complexity.

Local configurations and local coding created unique HIT features and functionality which may have been needed based on a hospital location or patient population while also creating variability from hospital to hospital possibly within the same health network. For the most part, these local variations had few initial negative consequences for patients and health practitioners. Unfortunately, most HIT configurations did not optimize for patient mobility – patients who received care in non-affiliated systems or for the need to share precision data with other agencies such as health registries and public health agencies.

Without new incentives, many organizations are unable to fully maintain aging HIT as vendor maintenance contract costs continue to increase. Also, experienced HIT personnel are more expensive as other technology companies search for qualified staff in a decreasing talent pool. Health systems have become more dependent on vendors to fill the talent gap. Some under-resourced hospitals may be forced to delay system upgrades and updates – even important changes in terminology, clinical workflows, naming and coding, or other critical data quality enhancements due to concerns over system failures, outages, or unexpected consequences from system updates. These are real concerns and may lead to patient safety implications. The recent CrowdStrike cybersecurity update failure in 2024 caused many health systems to cancel surgeries and other non-critical services leading to over $2 billion in losses to healthcare organizations. [36]

para.emphasis: Addressing patient safety gaps in the current health data ecosystem

section.para: Today, health data is critical to health care decisions. Mostly, we focus on data used to make clinical decisions because those decisions directly impact the treatment that patients receive, and the quality of care delivered. Clinical decision support systems (CDSS) depend on data accuracy and precision to ensure decision “triggers” fire when appropriate to prevent delays in treatment or diagnostic errors. If important clinical information is missing sufficient context, decision-making can be incorrect, insufficient, or incomplete. A laboratory test result that is missing units of measure, reference range, or unique device identification may not be used for decision-making prompting further testing, additional costs, and unnecessary patient suffering for intrusive tests. Patient history may not always be accurate or complete – especially when migrating data from one EHR to another especially when data migration is limited to recent history.

Many of the types of errors related to encoding, sharing, and exchanging health data remain difficult to manage safely since institutions are mostly interested in the quality of the data received rather than the data sent. The Assistant Secretary of Technology/Office of the National Coordinator for Health IT (ASTP) has developed the Trusted Exchange Framework and Common Agreement (TEFCA) to enhance data sharing and data exchange. The framework establishes policies, governance practices, and standards aimed at making health data more accessible for payers, public health agencies, provider organizations, and patients. TEFCA will likely enhance the data sharing infrastructure, it does not currently address the quality of data being shared. [37]

Data intended to be used for research needs to possess the attributes summarized in the Findability, Accessibility, Interoperability, and Reusability (FAIR) Guiding Principles, which provide guidelines to make data findable (F), accessible (A), interoperable (I) and reusable (R) to the research community and machines. Unfortunately, a large portion of health data does not meet the FAIR Guiding Principles as it is often hidden in isolated data silos and incompatible systems and difficult to exchange, process, and interpret. [38-39] During the COVID-19 pandemic, leaders were unable to make informed decisions related to public health because of incomplete data, unstructured data, and missing data leading to preventable patient deaths, pandemic response delays, and unnecessary lockdowns. [40]

para.emphasis: Spotlight Case Study #2: Analysis of laboratory data transmission between two healthcare institutions using a widely used point-to-point health information exchange platform: a case report

section.para: The objective of this analysis was to identify information loss that could affect clinical care in laboratory data transmission between two health care institutions via a Health Information Exchange (HIE) platform. To accomplish this, data transmission results of 9 laboratory tests of a simulated patient, including LOINC® codes, were compared in the following: between sending and receiving EHR systems, the individual HL7 Version 2 messages across the instrument, laboratory information system, and the sending EHR. The analysis found that the loss of information for this and similar tests indicated the following potential patient safety issues:

listitem.para: Consistently missing specimen source
Lack of reporting of analytical technique or instrument platform
Inconsistent units of measure and reference ranges
Discordant LOINC® code use
Increased data messaging complexity with multiple HL7 versions

section.para: This analysis showcased the challenges surrounding the completeness and accuracy of laboratory data exchanges in terms of the data elements required by law and the needed details to correctly interpret the results of the test. Additionally, this analysis highlighted the differences of manufacturers’ equipment (specifically in vitro devices) performing the same test on the same sample and the production of differing results. Furthermore, despite being key to correct interpretation, information on the equipment manufacturer that produced the result, and the type of sample tested was never included in the exchange results. The study concluded that while the SHIELD collaborative community recommendations can be helpful − such as consistently including encodement information (SNOMED CT® and LOINC®), Unified Codes for Units of Measure (UCUM), and Unique Device Identifier (UDI) – these are partial steps to improving laboratory data interoperability. In tandem, EHR and LIS functionality must be standardized to allow for the consistent capture and transmission of relevant data elements. Usage of a HIE with standard messaging, SHIELD recommendations, and enhanced EHR data encoding functionality can yield consistent test identification and result value transmission.

para.emphasis: Spotlight Case Study #3: Establishing Trust in Pharmaceutical Data with an Independent Verification and Validation (IV&V) Methodology

section.para: In this study, researchers demonstrated a general-purpose IV&V approach for information models, instance data, and knowledge that will enable reproducible metrics for data quality and patient safety. This IV&V approach uses established statistical process control methods for inter-rater and intra-rater reliability and agreement metrics with Cohen’s Kappa to evaluate pharmacy prescription data being migrated between a legacy EHR and commercial-off-the-shelf (COTS) EHR. These methods are widely accepted in other industries where quality and safety are closely monitored, but the methods are under-utilized within the HIT industry. The research team demonstrated that these methods can be applied to electronic health data and knowledge management tasks. Researchers recommended that HIT practitioners routinely use bivariate comparison of reviewer agreement over an appropriately sized statistical sample to develop standard benchmarks for health data and knowledge quality and safety. A detailed description of the method is provided in this study along with summarized analysis findings from the application of IV&V methods to pharmacy prescription data being migrated between EHRs.
